title: My attorney does not have my best interest in mind, can I change attorneys in the middle of my bankruptcy?
question: It is clear to me now that I am 5 months into my Chapter 7 Bankruptcy, that my attorney either made a huge mistake or he we negligent in telling me some very important information about my situation. If I choose to change my attorney now, can I do it? I have already paid my current attorney all of his fees, yet, now that he has my money, it seems as though he could care less what happens to myself and my family. What are the laws affecting me? Do I have any recourse when it comes to getting some money back for services NOT rendered?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Bankruptcy adversary proceeding,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Arbitration
answers: The fact that you have been in your BK for 5 months tells me something is wrong. If the case was FILED five months ago and you have not received a discharge, I suspect the trustee is evaluating certain assets for possible administration in the case. Since you did not disclose what information the attorney failed to tell you, no one can offer you much help and advice.

A judge once told me that honesty and sacrifice are the price of admission to bankruptcy court in order to seek relief from your debts. The Supreme Court has stated that the principal purpose of the Bankruptcy Code is to grant a "fresh start" to the “honest but unfortunate debtor”. You are free to change attorneys, but bear in mind that you will have to pay the new attorney and it sounds like most if not all of the work has been done. Your question is rather vague about why you feel that your attorney doesn't care about what happens to you and you haven't stated any concrete reasons to indicate that you are entitled to refund. You might as well try to talk to your current attorney because any new attorney will probably talk to the resolve the issue. Any new attorney will probably call the current attorney anyway to find out why the relationship went south.

Bankruptcy is a stressful process, it is has been my experience that debtor sometimes forget the advice their attorney gave them. This is particularly true when the debtor has maxed out the available exemption money to protect their assets. If they might lose an asset, they think that it is somehow the attorney's fault.

If your case has been open for 5 months, it sounds like the trustee has not concluded his or her investigation into the value of your assets. It is possibly that you could receive a discharge but the case could still remain open to allow the trustee to sell any unprotected assets. That is just part of the bankruptcy process.

You can change attorneys during the bankruptcy case by executing a substitution of attorneys, which is a simple form that notifies the court and trustee that your counsel has changed.

You also are entitled to a refund of the unearned fees that you've paid. But at 5 months into the case there may not be any fees that have not been earned. The California Bar maintains a fee arbitration program that helps clients recover such fees.

That said, I've never met an attorney that didn't care about his or her client. I'd encourage you to communicate your concerns with your current counsel, and give him the opportunity to demonstrate he is in your corner. There's no guarantee that hiring new counsel, or taking a matter before the fee arbitration panel, is going to change the outcome of a case.

I hope your case resolves with a good outcome for you.

You may be able to request a refund (partial or full, depending) on work already completed and/or errors of attorney if any. You should speak to your current counsel ASAP about your desire for a refund of amounts paid if you believe such is owed to you, offering the reasons to support your decision.

Yes, you may employ a new attorney following the conditions provided by local bankruptcy rules in your jurisdiction, some of which are provided here for your convenience:

Pursuant to Local Bankruptcy Rule 9010-5, the substitution of attorneys is governed by District Court Local Rule 83.3(g)(2) which states that attorney substitutions are to be approved by the court and signed by the party making the substitution, the attorney ceasing to act and the newly appointed attorney. Therefore, to facilitate the attorney substitution process and to comply with District Court Local Rule 83.3(g)(2), the court is implementing a new form and order CSD3011 - "Substitution Of Attorney And Order Thereon". The completed form is uploaded as an order through Order Upload (E-Orders) and will be entered upon court approval. The new form is now available on the court's forms website for download and use when attorney substitutions occur in bankruptcy cases and adversary proceedings filed at the court. Also, the procedures in the ECF Online Manual will be updated to reflect the order process and new form CSD 3011 - "Substitution Of Attorney And Order Thereon."
